ldquosignicant.Reflecting on the Mainetti announcement, he added: ldquoThis will be extremely dficult news for the workers and their families particularly at a time when there is so much uncertainty.ldquoIt is important that the PACE redundancy support is put in place by Scottish Borders Council and the Scottish Government as quickly as possible to give everyone affected all the help they need.ldquoI am also happy to assist any employees affected by this news.ldquoJedburgh urgently needs a stimulus package to boost economic growth in the area to allow it to recover from these signicant job lossesldquoI will be contacting the Scottish Government, the local council and the South of Scotland Economic Partnership to discuss how we can help the town and the wider Borders economy to recover after the impact of the coronavirus.Meanwhile, MSP Rachael Hamilton, also of the Conservatives, said she was very upset to learn about the threat to jobs in Jedburgh.The Holyrood member for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire said: ldquoI am devastated to hear of more damaging job cuts.ldquoThe financial impact will hit hard in a fragile rural area like the Borders.ldquoThe Scottish Government must plan now for an economic recovery and try to mitigate further job losses and ensure the people of the Borders can find alternative work opportunities.ldquoI am here to help as best I can, please do get in contactyou, a family member or a relative is affected.Jedburgh councillor Scott Hamilton said: ldquoThe people and businesses of Jedburgh are resilient but it is clear that we are not going to be immune to the impact of coronavirus on our economy.ldquoMainetti has provided good jobs for the people in this area so it will be a real shame to see their manufacturing plant shut.ldquoJedburgh will no doubt recover, but it is important that we get the help we need to be able to attract investment in our town to help economic growth in the future.

title: i-worry-seizure-even-though-medicine-works
story: A GALASHIELS schoolgirl with epilepsy has made a video to teach people about the condition.Lucy Millar gets seizures lasting up to  seconds due to childhood absence epilepsy .Now the nine-year-old wants to teach people how to react when someone has a seizure.Her father Bruce said he felt "pretty emotional" as his daughter crafted a YouTube video, which has gone on to achieve more than , views."Right from the start she wanted to reach as many people as possible to teach them about CAE ," said Mr Millar, whose daughter was diagnosed a year ago.Lucy said: "I feel more OK about it [CAE] because I know more about epilepsy now."Sometimes I worry that Ill have a seizure even though I know my medicine works."I dont think many people know there are dferent types of epilepsy andmore people know about it then its better for epileptics."I would like to teach people what to dosomeone they know has an absence seizure to make sure they are safe."Also to help people spot absence seizures with their children."This newspaper asked Mr Millar what advice he would give parents whose children have epilepsy.He said: "Take a deep breath ndash you might feel like youve been hit by a train, but theres a good chance your child is braver than you realise."He also recommended joining support groups and letting children with epilepsy socialise together.To watch Lucys video, you can click this link.

title: bike-library-helps-key-workers-borders
story: A "BIKE library" has been launched to help key workers during the coronavirus pandemic.Just Cycle and Momentum Scottish Borders, the employability service, started the project at the Tweedbank Craft Centre in March.Key workers have been encouraged to borrow bikes to help them travel to work.Peebles carer Amy, of Walkerburn, said she is "so grateful" for the scheme.She said: "I am much less anxious now as I have a better option to get to work and itrsquos a lot more manageable."I know other carers who would benefit from this and have texted my friend, who is also worried about getting to and from work, to let her know about the bikes."Just Cycle usually gets its recycled bikes from recycling centres around the Borders, but it struggled when the sites were closed.However, the project has been able to meet demand thanks to the kindness of Borders residents.Just Cycle manager Deborah Crozier said: "We put out a call on our Facebook page, requesting donations of unwanted bikes."As always, the Borders community answered our call, donating a further  bicycles."Cycling UK also got in touch to let us know about the Big Bike Revival for Key Workers fund that would allow us to restore more bikes to further support the bike library."We got the funding, and our socially distanced volunteer mechanics ndash Stephen, Andy and Grant ndash have been working flat out to restore, repair and recycle more bicycles."Momentum Scottish Borders Gillian Ormiston said the group received help from cycling product supplier Muc Off.The company provided antibacterial spray and cleaning products to ensure health and safety standards were upheld.Ms Ormiston said: "In my role, it was in my best interests to look at ways to contribute to keeping the Borders on the move."Sustaining and maintaining employment for the Scottish Borders is vital, even more so through this pandemic, to enable key workers to remain focused and on the move, and to support their everyday needs."For more information, visit the Just Cycle Facebook page at: www.facebook justcycle

title: borders-university-staff-make-ppe-key-workers
story: UNIVERSITY staff have made  sets of protective clothing for key workers.Staff at the Heriot-Watt campus, Galashiels, have been sewing scrubs since mid-May.Volunteer Jane Robertson said: "We are very happy to help and feel its our moral obligation to do so."The School of Design and Textiles, which has been using its own stock, plans to make  more sets of scrub.Head of school Fiona Waldron said: "Our staff who have come forward to volunteer have been a great inspiration and they are working hard, in social distancing conditions, to make as many scrubs as they can.ldquoIn these unprecedented timeswe can help even a few, then its worth it.The scrubs are made from  per cent cotton and can also be used after the pandemic, according to the university.The mini workshop was set up by four staff volunteers, who drew up the scrub designs.Ms Robertson said: ldquoWe have been joking that these will be the best-made scrubs in the country, as we are all finding it dficult to let the quality slip in order to sew them faster!The Heriot-Watt team has also been asked to make , cotton face masks for care homes.

title: blackout-tuesday-happening-can-get-involved
story: George Floyd ndash an African-American man ndash was handcuffed and lying face down on a city street as white American Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin kneeled on the right side of his neck on May .Chauvinrsquos knee remained there for eight minutes and  seconds, despite Floydrsquos repeated pleas of ldquoI canrsquot breathe ndash two minutes and  seconds of that time occurred after Floyd became unresponsive. He died in custody.The fallout has been far reaching, with dramatic clashes between protesters and police forces in many American cities over the past week.Demonstrations have alsobeen seen in countries across the world, despite much of the planet still under some form of lockdown from coronavirus.Today ndashTuesday,June  ndashmarks#BlackoutTuesday, a day when you will likely notice many of your favourite artists, websites and media outlets going dark across Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.Herersquos everything you need to know:What is #BlackoutTuesday Itrsquos hard to pinpoint exactly where the idea for#BlackoutTuesday comes from, but many are crediting music executivesJamila Thomas and Brianna Agyemang with getting the ball rolling with their#theshowmustbepaused initiative.An official websiteexplains that the social media movement is ldquomeant tointentionally disrupt the work weekhellipin observance of the long-standing racism and inequality that exists from the boardroom to the bouled".The music industry is a multi-billion dollar industry built on privilege, and one that has ldquoprofited prominently from black art.ldquoOur mission is to hold the industry at large, including major corporations and their partners who benefit from the efforts, struggles and successes of Black people accountable, says the website.Despite the name lsquoBlackout Tuesdayrsquo being attribute to it,Thomas and Agyemang say: ldquoThis is not just a -hour initiative. We are and will be in this fight for the long haul."What is happening Major musical artistslike the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and Quincy Jones havesaid they will observe the day.No hard and fast lsquorulesrsquo have been set on how to show support for the initiative, but it seems asat the very minimum, bands and artists will be modying their social media profiles, changing cover images and display pictures to the colour black.They will also not be posting across social media channelsa number of artists have also cancelled listening parties or fan events.Spoty will add eight minutes and  seconds of silence to selected playlists and podcasts, reflecting theof timeDerek Chauvin an aggressive knee was applied to the side of George Floyds neck.Major record labels like Def Jam, Interscope, Sony Music, Columbia Records, and more are also expected to participate.,params: .pushMusic-based companies such as Live Nation and TikTok have announced that they will support and stand with the black community.Independent bands and labels from across the world will also be lending their support to this most worthy of causes.Who  is taking part While #TheShowMustBePaused and #BlackoutTuesday originated in the music industry, word of the movement has inevitably spread.Now representatives across many dferent industries from entertainment and beyond are lending their support to the cause.Celebrities from the world of film and TV have also vowed to take part, and in America, a number of television networks will go dark for eightminutes and  seconds in honour of Floyd.MTV ldquowill not hold any meetings nor conduct any businesshellip in solidarity with our African American colleagues and loved ones across the country, according toChris McCarthy, president of the ViacomCBS Entertainment  Youth Group.How can I get involved There are a number of ways you can get involved and show your support for #BlackoutTuesdayand the Black Lives Matter movement.Blacking out your social media profiles is a first step, buttheshowmustbepausedlists further suggestions as to how you can make a dference, and enact positive change:If you have been impacted by the recent events, take a break - there is a lot going on and sometimes we all just need a minute. Take that minute...Help the family of George Floyd -www.gofundme f georgefloydFight for Breonna Taylor -justiceforbreonna.org Help the family of Ahmaud Arbery -www.gofundme f i-run-with-maudWant to help protesters  Donate to one or more community bail funds -https:secure.actblue donate bail_funds_george_floydVisit Movement For Black Lives for additional ways you can help the cause -mbl.orgWant to connect with leaders building grass roots campaigns  -www.untilfreedom

title: martin-lewis-issues-important-advice-homeowners-mortgage-holidays
story: Martin Lewis has released important advice on mortgages for all homeownersacross the country.The MoneySavingExpertshared informationon three-month mortgage holidays, which follows an update bytheFinancial Conduct Authority .What has Martin said Martin said: "Under the regulators plans, you willhave untilOctober to apply for one, and those who have already had one can extend."Yet interest racks up and it can impact you creditworthiness."My hope is that as these holidays are specically for the short-term financial hit of coronavirus,and as the practice is so widespread, it wont be used by many firms, and where it is it wont tarnish iniduals credit reputation for too long."But theres no real way to know. Most importantly, I dont believe this should stop anyone who needs a mortgage holiday from getting one."If its crucial for cash flow, just do it."Yet for those on the border, who may find it temporarily useful but can cope without it, add this to the fact that interest racks up during the payment holiday and Id err on the side of caution."What have the FCA said Christopher Woolard, interim chief executive at the FCA, said: "Our expectations are clear - anyone who continues to need help should get help from their lender."We expect firms to work with customers on the best options available for them, paying particular attention to the needs of their vulnerable customers, and to provide information on where to access help and advice."Where consumers can afford to restart mortgage payments, it is in their best interests to do so. But where they cant, a range of further support will be available."People who are struggling and have not had a payment holiday will continue to be able to apply until October ."What have UK Finance said Stephen Jones, the CEO of UK Finance, said: "Banks and building societies will continue to help their customers get through the crisis and have a wide range of support available."Anyone with concerns about their financial situation should check with their lender to discuss which form of support would be the best choice for them."

title: mcdonalds-galashiels-site-reopens-drive-thru
story: McDONALDS in Galashiels has reopened its drive-thru service after closing due to the coronavirus pandemic.Safety measures are in place at the Wilderhaugh site, which is running with reduced staff.The drive-thru opened at am today with a limited menu.McDonalds says it expects a "high demand" at all of its reopened sites.The fast food chain has issued a list of the safety measures being rolled out.These are the new measures at McDonaldsSocial distancing in kitchens and service areasPerspex screens at drive-thru windowsProtective equipment for staffFloor markings in the premisesAll staff will be asked to confirm they are healthy and able to work andcontactless thermometers will be used to take employees temperatures on arrival for every shtRestaurants willwith smaller teams, offering a limited menuand operating reduced hoursEncouraging capped spendat pound per order, with customers encouraged to pay by contactless methodsDrive-thru customers can browse the menu, order and pay ahead using the My McDonaldrsquos app

title: scots-urged-take-knee-doorsteps-solidarity-george-floyd-tonight
story: People across Scotland are being asked to show their solidarity with George Floyd on their doorsteps this evening as protests in America continue.Anti-racism campaigners Stand Up to Racism are urging people to take the knee on Wednesday night in a socially-distanced protest in response to the death of Floyd, who died in police custody.The -year-old died last week after a police officer held him down by pressing his knee into his neck.The US has since erupted in riots from people demanding justice, and other countries across the world have begun to take action.People in the UK are being asked to kneel at their doorsteps at pm on Wednesday.They say the demonstration has been inspired by the kneeling protests first staged by American football star Colin Kaepernick in .ldquoWe send our condolences, and stand in solidarity with all those demanding justice right now from deaths resulting from contact with the policemdashfrom Minnesota to Kirkcaldy," said Talat Ahmed, STUCs Scotland Convenor."As we demand justice for George Floyd we also remember Sheku Bayoh, who like Floyd said, I cant breathe, while being brutally restrained by police five years ago here in Scotland."We welcome the First Ministers support for the Black Lives Matter movement. But we also support the call from the Scottish Trades Union Congresss Black Workers Committee on the Scottish government for more openness about the impact of coronavirus on BAME communities here in Scotland."We call on Scottish MPs to back the EDM at Westminster for a public inquiry into the disproportionate impact of Covid- on BAME communities."Several protests had been organised throughout Scotland, however First Minister Nicola Sturgeon advised protesters to avoid large groups.Ms Sturgeon backed the Black Lives Matter movement, saying she sympathised with those looking to protest, but warned of the risks involved with gathering due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.She said: "Right now, it is the case, unfortunately, and regrettably, that large gatherings of people could pose a risk to health and indeed to le."Unfortunately, thats the case whether it is a peaceful protest or a football match or any other gathering where people are coming together in close proximity."What I would say to those who want to protest, and I say this as an ally and supporter, is that we need to find ways of allowing people to make their voices heard and to make the points that many of us want to be made and to be heard right now but to do so in a way that is safe and is not putting people protesting or wider communities at risk."

title: ibuprofen-tested-possible-treatment-reduce-covid-19-symptom
story: Scientists have begun a new trial to determine whether ibuprofen might hold the key to preventing severe breathing problems inCOVID- patients.Heres what you need to know.Why has the new trial started Experts are assessing whether a special formulation of thedrug could help reduce the serious side effect seen among patients infected withcoronavirus.It is hoped that the cheap anti-inflammatory drug could reduce severe respiratory illness when delivered at a certain point tohospital patients.This could potentially lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer patients needing help in intensive care units .The trial is for hospitalised patientsMitul Mehta, professor of neuroimaging and psychopharmacology and director of Centre for Innovative Therapeutics at Kings College London, told the PA news agency: ldquoItrsquos a trial for patients with COVID- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug ndash a specic form of ibuprofen ndash will reduce the respiratory problems they have.He stressed that the trial was for hospitalised patients ndash not those who have mild or suspected COVID-.Participants will be drawn from those who are hospitalised, but not so ill they are in need of intensive care.ldquoAndwe can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits: we could reduce the amount of time that someone spends in hospital ndash they might recover quicker and go home, thatrsquos obviously a fantastic outcome we also might be reducing the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU. And that is a fantastic outcome as well.ldquoTheoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.ldquoBut of course, this is based on animal studies. Itrsquos based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.What have other studies found so far Prof Mehta said that animal studies into acute respiratory distress syndrome ndash a symptom of COVID- disease ndash showthat about  per cent of animals with this condition die.But when they are given this special formulation of ibuprofen, the survival rates increase to  per cent.ldquoThis is very promising, he added. ldquoBut of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.How will the trial work The Liberate trial is a joint effort between experts from Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust, Kingrsquos College London and the pharmaceutical organisation the SEEK Group.Half of the patients enrolled in the trial will receive standard care and the other half will receive standard care plus the special ibuprofen formulation.,params: .pushIt is hoped that the way the drug has been formulated will reduce potential gastric side effects linked to ibuprofen.Professor Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: ldquoThis highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment."If successful, the global public health value of this trial result would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Early on in the pandemic, there was controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against the use of it.Scientists in Britain launched a review to assess ties to the drug and COVID-.The Commission on Human Medicinesrsquo expert working group concluded: ldquoThere is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of its symptoms.

title: peebles-callants-keep-town-looking-good-annual-clean
story: DESPITE this years Beltane Festival being cancelled due to coronavirus, the Callants still turned out to keep Peebles clean and "looking good".Around  volunteers gathered on Sundayat am to remove weeds and litter across central areas of the town.The clean-up, held before the Beltane each year, collected more than  bags of weeds this time round.The High Street, Eastgate, Northgate and the Old Town were all looked after by the volunteers, who were armed with garden tools, gloves and high-vis vests.Chief Callant Andrew Williamson told the Peeblesshire News: "This year, because of lockdown, council workers are not out, so the town has more weeds than usual."We had one or two comments online so we brought the clean-up forward."We would usually do it the Sunday before Beltane."Mr Williamson, , said Tweed Bridge and Cuddy Bridge also received the clean-up treatment a fortnight ago.He added that after both events, the town is now "looking good".Across the Borders, summer festivals have been cancelled, including West Lintons Whipman Play and Innerleithens St Ronans Border Games.The Chief Callant described how he felt about the cancellation of this years celebrations.He said: "Its disappointing, but there is not much we can do."The last time the festival stopped was probably World War Two."But every festival is the same. Well have to come back next year bigger and better than before."Updates on the Beltane Festival  can be found on the festivals Facebook page at: www.facebook PeeblesBeltaneFestival

title: tourists-slammed-driving-borders-making-diy-loo
story: CITY residents have been accused of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for Peebles by travelling to the town and breaching lockdown rules.The chairman of Peebles Community Council says visitors from Edinburgh were spoken to by police at the weekend.Les Turnbull said: ldquoI am disappointed that the police did not take more positive action to prosecute these offenders.Relaxed lockdown measures were introduced last Friday , allowing Scots to meet up with one other household outdoors as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight people and everyone stays two metres apart.Travelling short distances for leisure and exercise is permitted, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon recommending that no-one goes further than five miles from their home.However, Mr Turnbull says police spoke to visitors from Edinburgh at the weekend after reports that three vehicles had parked up in Hay Lodge Park, Peebles, next to Fotheringham Bridge.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt would appear that the occupants of these vehicles had removed the chain securing the gate in South Parks Industrial Estate to gain access before parking up and erecting what appeared to be a makesht toilet behind a screen.Police are understood to have issued advice to the group, who claimed they had found the gate open. They packed up and left soon after being spoken to.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt beggars belief that these visitors from Edinburgh feel they can drive to Peebles, go through a gate which is chained, and park up on what is clearly park land.ldquoTo then erect what seems to be a toilet on the grass near Fotheringham Bridge really is a step too far.ldquoWhere any of this human waste was dumped, is a question I would like answering.Mr Turnbull says he has asked council officials to make sure the gate is secured with a ldquoheavy padlock.The community leader believes misbehaving visitors are guilty of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for the regulations and the people of Peebles.He added: ldquoAs the town begins to recover from this crisis, we do want and need visitors to come and enjoy what we have to offer, but is it too much to ask for them to be respectful and responsible Chief Inspector Stuart Reid said: "The current regulations are clear: people should only leave the house for very limited purposes, for example for basic necessities, for exercise or recreation, for medical needs or travelling for work which cannot be done from home."We are asking people to take personal responsibility to do the right thing and remember the purpose of these measures is to aid the collective effort to protect the NHS and save lives by preventing the virus from spreading."Our officers will continue to engage with the public, explain the legislation and guidance and encourage compliance."We will use enforcement as a last resort only where there is a clear breach of the legislation."

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The UKis to be graced by a Strawberry Moon this week in a rare lunar event that will lightup the skies.The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST on Friday evening.According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three tofour days.

title: coronavirus-make-face-mask
story: YOUVE probably heard by now that wearingface coverings in Scotlands public placescould become mandatory in the future.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this was under consideration in her daily briefing yesterday, but stressed there is no timescale on when the wearing of one mightenforced across the country.Ms Sturgeon was keen to emphasise medical face masks should be prioritised for frontline workers and instead has encouraged Scots to make their own face coverings from home.Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:Elastic band or hair tiesBandanaHandkerchiefT-shirtScissorsKitchen towelPinsNeedle and threadWhat are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all timesStore used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash themWash a face covering regularly - it can go in with other laundry, using your normal detergentThe one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.,params: .pushHeres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: borders-builder-saves-35-jobs-bank-loan
story: A BORDERS builder has saved  jobs after receiving a six-figure loan.Melroses Rural Renaissance Ltd , the parent company of JS Crawford, put  full-time staff on furlough due to the coronavirus shutdown.But the workers futures are now safe after Bank of Scotlandagreed to issue a loan.The banks relationship director Douglas Spowart said: "The funding has secured the future of the business alongside the jobs of its  members of staff.JS Crawford Group is one of the largest builders in the region, with sites in Melrose, Kelso and Galashiels.RRL managing director Michael Crawford said: ldquoWe were set for further success this year until the COVID- crisis hit."As with many other businesses, much of our activity is now on hold.ldquoThe financial support means wersquove been able to pay our suppliers and support our staff.ldquoWersquore a big part of the community here, so itrsquos really important to us as a company that wersquore able to meet our commitments.Once lockdown has ended, the firm aims to start three projects in the Borders.Seven large houses are planned for Orchard Park, Gattonside, while Galashiels is due to see a mix of detached and semi-detached homes at the Old Tennis Courts on Abbotsford Road.Luxury flats and a health spa, planned for Melrose, are awaiting planning permission.Mr Crawford said the bank has helped RRL through "cash flow challenges, ensuring we have the financial headspace needed to continue to trade".Mr Spowart, of the bank, added: ldquoWersquove worked with RRL to put a package in place that, critically, the business can afford to repay."RRL achieved a turnover of pound million in .

title: borders-urged-stay-within-five-miles-home
story: BORDERS residents are being reminded that they should stay within five miles of their home under the updated lockdown guidance.Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan has thanked people for staying at home as much as possible during the coronavirus pandemic.But Ms Logan is urging households to remain within five miles of their front doorthey do travel for exercise or recreation.She said: ldquoWhile we have so many beautul places to visit in our region, Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.Lockdown rules were relaxed slightly on May , meaning people can now meet up with one other household outside, as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight and everyone follows social distancing guidelines.Ms Logan said: ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom, Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.Meanwhile, NHS Borders chief executive Ralph Roberts also thanked residents for obeying guidelines so far.He said this has helped drive down the number of virus patients in the region, adding that the health board has ldquosignicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for such patients.However, Mr Roberts said circumstances can ldquoeasily change.He said: "COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends.The full statement from Tracey Logan"Weve only been able to reach this stage thanks to our residents staying at home, only making essential journeys, observing social distancing guidelines and washing their hands regularly."I want to thank everyone for playing their part."We can now meet up with other households outdoors and I know families and friends across the Borders have been making the most of the opportunity to see each other again."You do still need to keep at least two metres apart, though, stay outdoors, and wash your hands regularly."People are now allowed to sit in parks and open areas, and travel within their local area for exercise or recreation."While we have so many beautul places to visit in our region Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.ldquoWe have been able to ease restrictions on some services such as reopening community recycling centres but other council facilities such as playparks and public toilets remain closed.ldquoI also know residents who are currently shielding are being asked to remain at home for the time being."I realise the sacrices these people are having to make but would like to reassure them that we will continue to give them all the support they need."Our Community Assistance Hubs can provide help with food, shopping and delivery of medication as well as regular check-ins to see that everything is okay."If anyone needs support please visit our website or call   .The full statement from Ralph RobertsldquoI would like to take the opportunity to thank everyone in the Borders for the co-operation you have shown over the last two months in following the guidance on lockdown and restriction of movement."All of us in the NHS are very conscious that this has been dficult and will have had a lasting impact on many people in our community."However, I am pleased to emphasise that this has worked so far and as a local NHS we have been able to care for all the COVID patients we have seen, whether that was in the community or for those more seriously ill in hospital."I am also pleased to advise that over the last month we have seen a steady reduction of patients in hospital who have had or been suspected of having COVID."We have therefore now signicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for COVID patients."However I recognise that this can easily change and I would therefore encourage everyone to continue to follow the Scottish Government advice as we ease lockdown.,params: .push"Please also remember to follow the advice on hand hygiene, physical distancing and self-isolationyou or a family member is experiencing any symptoms of the virus."COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends."We are now working hard to look at how we can reintroduce the services we needed to pause while we responded to COVID."Because of the continuing risk with COVID this will mean though that some of our services will be provided dferently so that we can keep our patients and staff safe."I would therefore ask that you follow any information or requests that are madeyou need to attend one of our healthcare premises."Please remember that the NHS is open and should you have any concerns about your health please do not hesitate to contact us through the normal routes."UPDATE -.pm, June , -The words for exercise or recreation have been added to the end of the third paragraph of this article.

title: many-key-workers-borders
story: KEY workers make up more than a third of the Borders workforce, statistics show.The term lsquokey workerrsquo describes a person who is essential to the coronavirus response, including health and social care staff, supermarket employees and delivery drivers.Figures published by the Office for National Statistics show the Borders was home to a total of , key workers in .The figure equates to . per cent of the regionrsquos workforce ndash a slightly greater proportion than the UK average .Across Scotland and the rest of the UK, health and social care staff make up the greatest proportion of key workers.A separate analysis by jobs website Check-a-Salary shows the average salary for a full-time key worker in Scotland is pound,.For comparison, a person working  hours a week on the real Living Wagegets paid pound,.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: walkers-told-not-feed-wild-ponies
story: It comes after reports were made that people are feeding the ponies, who are wild and eat the grass and flowers at both locations.A Countryside Rangers statement said: ldquoItrsquos essential that the public do not feed them.ldquoWe need them to graze the Laws.A council spokesperson added: ldquoAlthough there have been signs at both Laws in place for a number of years advising visitors not to feed the ponies, we have had to issue reminders via social media as it appears people have been visiting and feeding the ponies.The spokesperson added that the ponies did not need extra feeding, as the terrain they live on provides all their essential food.The ponies were brought to the Laws to reduce grass vegetation and allow other plants to grow through.The council spokesperson also said that, by feeding the ponies, visitors would change the animalsrsquo behaviour, meaning they would come to expect to be fed.This could cause concern to other walkers who might be scared of horses.

title: golden-couple-toast-marriage-milestone-lockdown
story: John and Jean Hamilton marked  years of married bliss last Saturday at their home in Prestonpans.However, lockdown restrictions meant the couple were not able to share the day with their two sons or seven grandchildren.John, , and Jean, , met at the Labour Club in Prestonpans in , before tying the knot at Prestonpans Registry Office in May the following year.They have two sons, David, , and Andrew, .John, originally of Prestonpans, worked as a telephone engineer with BT, while Jean, who is from Cockenzie and Port Seton, worked as a secretary before going on to work at Muirfield Care Home.The couple advised that sharing and facing everything together was the secret to their y marriage, with the couple hoping to have a celebratory meal with their family once the restrictions are lted.In the meantime, Jean said there was not much to do to mark the occasion but joked about doing a waltz in the living room with Johnrsquos zimmer.Their family said: ldquoHappy th wedding anniversary! Love Andrew, Deborah, Nicole, Calum and Rebecca.

title: big-drive-adopt-street-keep-clean
story: The lsquoAdopt a Streetrsquo campaign, launched by the environmental group Love Musselburgh, has been gathering momentum with a band of volunteers offering to keep streets, parks and beaches rubbish free.Melanie Roccio, of Love Musselburgh, said those involved are given litter-picking sticks and clean up their lsquoadoptedrsquo area whenever they wish.She said: ldquoItrsquos a very casual arrangement: there are no minimum or maximum number of times to pick and no targets to reach. I wanted this to be a zero pressure thing.ldquoDuring the Covid crisis, Irsquove not actively encouraged litter picking but am grateful to those who continue to do so.She urged more volunteers to step forward to lsquoAdopt a Streetrsquo in the future.She said: ldquoThe Covid situation has been devastating. But the sense of community has definitely increased and more people are looking out for each other, whether thatrsquos friends, neighbours or strangers.ldquoTherersquos an openness to talk with and smile at others and a real desire to use small, local businesses that may be struggling at this time."I also love the creativity that has been visible throughout the town in the form of chalk drawings,painted stones and rainbows in windows.She added: ldquoI naively thought there would be less litter during lockdown but it seems that disposable gloves and masks have replaced the usual fast food chain packaging.ldquoAdopting a street is a great way to get out and about, meet people and do something good in the community.ldquoWe have nearly  iniduals, families and businesses signed up now but Irsquod love to see that list continue to grow.ldquoOnce lockdown ends it would be great to know there are even more areas being cared for.Councillor John Williamson said Love Musselburgh were doing a wonderful job encouraging locals to take pride in their community and to help make the town a cleaner, greener place for all.ldquoThe Adopt a Street initiative is a great way of letting people do their bit by taking on as much litter picking in a local street, or part of a street, as they feel able to do, he added.ldquoThey can also adopt a local park or bit of beach as well. Of course there would be no litter problempeople disposed of their litter properly either by taking it home or putting it in a litter bin.Councillor Andy Forrest said: ldquoThere has always been a working partnership between East Lothian Councilrsquos landscape and countryside department and Love Musselburgh.ldquoMelanie Roccio and all the volunteers are really committed. We do anything we can to support them and they support the council.Local residents took to social media to give their views on the campaign: Robin Wallace said: ldquoI joined up because Irsquom fed up of seeing rubbish on our streets. Despite the plastic problem in our ocean, I still find bottles everywhere, even close to bins. So, I wanted to help, evenjust small.Susan Stevens added: ldquoIrsquove adopted Denholm Road which has the path at the back of it and a playpark off it. ldquoThe biggest issue Irsquove had is broken glass which gets smashed in amongst the trees where teenagers sit and all around the power house in the park. Also, litter caught in the bushes at the play area are from recycling boxes.Mel Hindley said online that her family adopted their street and her little boy loved nothing more than going up and down with his litter picker!ldquoWe have a charity based on our little street who bought him a gt to say thanks when he had been doing it a while ndash they hadnrsquot realised that some of their service users were sadly also serial litter droppers and that a five-year-old was cleaning up after them! she wrote.ldquoMy wee one was delighted and it felt like a lovely way of illustrating that good things happen when you do something for others. We think the campaign is a great way to help people take pride in where they live itrsquos just a shame that a minority think itrsquos OK to fly tip and drop rubbish where we live.While Pauline Clark, of Park Drive, Wallyford, said: ldquoThe strip in front of my house seems to attract litter: cans and bottles which are dangerous as some children play in that area. My son quite enjoys the challenge [of tidying it up].To get involved in Adopt a Street go to www.facebook lovemusselburgh

title: key-worker-demonstrating-pedal-power-pegasus-e-bike
story: Lidia Josvai, , a support worker, is getting to work using pedal power thanks to an offer from Play Together on Pedals ndash a cycling programme for children and families which expanded from Edinburgh to East Lothian last month.When coronavirus hit, the group could not run any of its normal rides, drop in sessions or family workshops, so it considered other ways to help people during the lockdown.Along with another Cycling UK project, Edinburgh All Ability Bike Centre, they made all their adult bikes available to key workers to get to and from work without having to use public transport.Lidia, who had not cycled in years, borrowed one of the electric bikes on offer and loves using it so much she has named it Peggy, after Pegasus, the mythical winged horse.Previously, she took the bus for the three-mile journey from her home to work at the Thistle Foundation in Craigmillar, Edinburgh ndash a health and wellbeing charity that supports people living with long-term conditions.Now she is enjoying the fresh air, birdsong and scenery on her half hour journey by bike. When shersquos not at work, Lidia has also been exploring new areas of Musselburgh since moving there three years ago.She said: ldquoI need exercise to help with back pain but I used to just come home from work and watch TV ndash I didnrsquot feel like doing any exercise. Now I canrsquot wait to get on the bike and explore. I love riding on the promenade as it doesnrsquot feel like exercise - itrsquos just fun.The last time Lidia cycled was in Budapest with her children.She added: ldquoThat was  years ago and they are now adults. Riding Peggy has given me my confidence back. She has changed my le.Cycling UKrsquos Angie Kinghorn, who runs Play Together on Pedals in Edinburgh, East Lothian and the Scottish Borders, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that our bikes are being put to good use by local key workers like Lidia. Itrsquos fantastic to hear that shersquos really enjoying cycling and that it has boosted her confidence.ldquoMany people are using cycling as a safe way to get from A to B during the lockdown, while others are finding itrsquos a real boost to their health and wellbeing. When itrsquos safe to do so we look forward to bringing our family cycling project to East Lothian, but, in the meantime, we canrsquot think of a better use for the bikes.Play Together on Pedals, funded by Transport Scotland, is a partnership between Cycling UK, Cycling Scotland and Play Scotland.

title: plans-ambitious-dunbear-park-set-revealed-public
story: DunBear Park has been designed around The DunBear sculpture, which was unveiled last year.The development, which is on land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store and garden centre, is being proposed by Hallhill Developments Ltd.The site includes retail and leisure units, drive-thru units, a hotel, offices, a nursery, care home and elderly amenity flats, as well as industrial and storage units.The plans also include  low carbon affordable homes for rent, which will be aimed at key workers, such as NHS staff, police and care workers.Representatives from the developer were on hand online to discuss the proposals during last weekrsquos meeting with the townrsquos community council.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the community council, said: ldquoWhat has become clear is the development is very, very much at the concept stage.ldquoIt is actually really refreshing to have an opportunity to be involved in the conversation about development well before it becomes fully resolved.Assurances have been sought that the type of businesses looking to move onto the .-acre site would not be duplicating those already in the town centre, while concerns about traffic accessing and leaving the site were also raised.Philip Mellor, owner of the Dunmuir Hotel and chairman of Dunbar Tradesrsquo Association, was also part of the online meeting.He said: ldquoThe traders certainly support activity in that area as long as it is done in the right mind and we do not end up with two split towns ndash an old town and the new town.Discussions have already taken place with the developer with a view to ensuring there are appropriate signs in place to point people in the direction of the established town centre.Mr Mellor felt integration and infrastructure were key to the development and was pleased to see the idea of a visitor centre included within the plans.Ken Ross, from the developer, encouraged people to view the plans on Wednesday afternoon.He said: ldquoWe are delighted to be putting forward our proposals to the local community for this exciting low carbon development and look forward to its involvement in shaping these proposals.ldquoDunBear Park will assist in creating jobs and delivering much-needed housing for key workers.ldquoIt will also assist in supporting the construction-led recovery from the current crisis.ldquoWe are seeking to deliver is an exemplar development, which not only Dunbar, but East Lothian and Scotland can be proud.ldquoThe support of the community will be crucial in achieving this.To view the proposals, go to www.dunbearpark planning between pm and pm tomorrow .Hard copies of consultation boards and feedback forms can be obtained following the event by writing to DunBear Park, c o Orbit Communications,  Queen Street, Edinburgh EH JE or by phoning   .Feedback can be submitted up to June .

title: grannys-stone-art-bringing-joy-town
story: Linda Donachie, , who lives in the Pinkie area, is leaving the colourful keepsakes all over the town for people to find while they are enjoying their daily exercise.She said: ldquoThey can keep them or leave them for others to find.Mrs Donachie, who retired three years ago after  years as the special needs auxiliary at Macmerry Primary School, said she had always looked at dferent craft and sensory ideas for her work.A mum of two and grandmum of four, she collects stones which catch her eye while out for a daily cycle to Morrisonrsquos Haven near Prestonpans with husband David.Back home, she decorates them with faces, sea creatures, hedgehogs, colourful patterns and flowers before leaving them at ious points in the town, including the sea wall, lagoons and Fisherrow harbour. One with a sad face was left at The Grove where a tree had been felled recently.Lucky finders have taken to social media to express their delight for lsquoLinda Drsquo who signs the stones, and she is overwhelmed by the positive feedback about her fun lockdown initiative.Jamie Wilson, of Levenhall, posted: ldquoWe found a magic painted stone on our garden wall. As much as we would love to keep this special stone we have decided to share the joy it brought us so will be passing it on for others to find. Thanks Linda D.Mrs Donachie said: ldquoI am planning to keep on doing it as I get pleasure out of it and always want to make children smile.She has also left stones for friends and posted some to her sisterrsquos grandchildren in Fe, as she lives in Haddington and canrsquot visit them due to the lockdown.Mrs Donachie and her husband also put their craft skills into action by making fun animals for friends and family out of discarded car parts.

title: daily-lockdown-exercise-inspires-artists-work
story: Andrew Siddall, who lives just off Fisherrow Links, is drawing views around the harbour from photographs he takes while out walking with his children during lockdown.He has turned some of his sketches into prints and is seeking commissions, big or small, to draw peoplersquos houses, special places as commemorative gts or to document particular places of interest for posterity.Mr Siddall teaches drawing and design at Edinburgh Universityrsquos College of Art and spends most of the spring and autumn at the college.He explained: ldquoI use the longer days to get out and about in East Lothianrsquos erse town and landscapes to draw places and capture the spirit of our region through carefully observed hand drawings.One of his favourite subjects throughout the year are the boats and yachts at Fisherrow harbour, and his daily exercise near his home has meant that he can continue to record scenes during the lockdown.He is also backing the current national initiative to support artists during the pandemic ndash called the #artistsupportpledge ndash which was set up by East Sussex artist Matthew Burrows.Any artist offers work up to a maximum value of pound and, when they have made pound, in sales , they commit  per cent of their takings to buy another artistrsquos work within the scheme.The initiative now has more than , posts and has generated an estimated pound million for artists and makers across the globe.After graduating from the Royal College of Art in London in the early s, Mr Siddall worked in architecture and public art for around  years.He said: ldquoI started drawing regularly again just a few years ago as it was something I always loved doing but found increasingly missing in professional le.His work is always based on fine line drawings of places, which then become digitally coloured prints or the foundations for paintings, depending on the time and situation.He exhibits and runs private drawing lessons during the summer months, and has a growing following online.He can often be found on the streets with a small sketchbook doing a daily urban sketch, and joins in with the regular Edinburgh Urban Sketchers meet-ups, where drawing the city from le provides a weekly social and creative chance to visit new places and share drawings.He commented: ldquoThere is always plenty of creative work to do but the current lockdown is a challenge, as much of my work is drawing lsquoon locationrsquo and working with communities through public art projects.Mr Siddall is also part of a group project called the #DaysProjectScotland, which involves artists from across the country creating a small piece of work every day for  days.He said: ldquoWersquore not sure whether wersquoll be able to run an exhibition this year but hopefully, by late August, we might have a little more freedom.ldquoThis year I will be making detailed aerial drawings of buildings through the centre of Edinburgh ndash a project I started last year but havenrsquot been able to get back to.He added: ldquoSimilar to keeping in touch with friends and family, keeping lsquovirtuallyrsquo connected with my artist friends provides a sense of normality and continuity at the moment.ldquoNone of us knows how long the current situation will last and wersquore really missing being out drawing from le but the social aspect of making art is almost as important as the process of drawing itself. The  Days project and the daily walks around Musselburgh will keep me busy.Mr Siddall can be contacted by email via andy@siddalldrawing.To see his work, there are regular posts on Instagram at instagram siddall_drawing or Facebook at facebook siddalldrawing

title: community-kitchen-reaches-tasty-milestone-1-000-meals
story: Our Community Kitchenwas set up more than two years ago in a bid to tackle social isolation throughout Haddington.Originally, the group brought people together to enjoy a hot meal but, with the coronavirus ensuring more and more people were staying at home, they changed their model.Now, more than , piping hot meals have been delivered to the doors of people in the community.Elaine Gale, founder of the group, was delighted to reach the milestone and thanked everyone involved.She said: ldquoThe whole community is amazing, it is just overwhelming.ldquoCommunity support has been completely incredible and really overwhelming.ldquoEarlier this month, we were celebrating , free hot meals being delivered to local people.A resilience team, headed up by Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, was formed as coronavirus restrictions came into place.Volunteers have collected shopping and prescriptions, with Our Community Kitchen, based within Haddington Bowling Club, creating a team of volunteers who have been dishing up freshly prepared meals to be delivered throughout the town.Social distancing restrictions have been put in place at the bowling club to allow volunteers to cook a range of hearty dishes, including chicken casserole, tuna pasta bake and corned beef stovies with red cabbage.The dishes are then delivered to people from throughout the town, with every step taken to ensure the meals are piping hot.Glowing reviews and passionate feedback have also been left with the group, who send out the hot meals three days a week.Ms Gale added: ldquoIt just goes to show you how simple hot food is making people cared for, thought about and loved.Various groups had made donations to support the cause, including the community council, Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnershipand Haddington Business Community Partnership.Representatives of the groups and members of the public have also come forward to offer their support. However, it is not just meals that are helping to put a smile on peoplersquos faces.Ms Gale added: ldquoWersquove got a newsletter goes out every fortnight with the meals. We also have the Rotary Club delivering the Courier to everyone, which was really lovely.ldquoThat goes out to everybodyrsquos home that a meal was delivered to. We have been doing kindness calls so we will be calling people at home and just asking how they are and seeingthere is anything we can do for people.

title: runner-takes-knitting-needles-charity
story: Margaret, , started the venture after being told by a friend that a community midwe was looking for people to knit medical workers wearing masks.She knitted a few for the midwe and sent them to her.Then she began knitting medical figures for family members who work in the medical profession, as well as one for Drummohr Care Home in Wallyford, where her dad is currently a resident. The doll, said Margaret, ldquoput a smile on the faces of the staff there.She then knitted a postman for her local post office in Tranent, as her brother works for the Post Office and previously managed the Haddington branch.Since then, the figures have been dotted around the neighbourhood, including on a lamppost outside Margaretrsquos house in Winton Close and on a bus shelter nearby.She has also taken to knitting figures for her neighbours, who then donate to NHS Charities Together.Margaret has also not stopped walking, and completed  laps of her house on April  for the . challenge on behalf of Walk The Walk, an event Margaret has taken part in for  years and which raises money for breast cancer charities.The event sees people donning decorated and colourful bras, with Margaret this year decorating hers with  colourful hearts, which her neighbours then bought to help raise pound.She was also due to take part in the Edinburgh marathon last weekend, but instead ran the  miles in her local area.

title: lucy-makes-home-left-stranded-australia
story: Lucy Hall made the trip of a letime Down Under with a view to working with animals.However, the global pandemic saw the -year-old left without a job, and restrictions meant she was unable to fly home.Lucy finally arrived home in Dunbar on April  after two flights and a train journey, which took about  hours.She said: ldquoEvery seat was filled on the first flight which was a bit daunting.ldquoThere were people of all ages and ethnicities.ldquoThe people that I got chatting to were all in a similar situation to me, all trying to get home and had their struggles along the way.The former Scottish Widows retirement specialist had been in Melbourne for less than a month when lockdown restrictions got under way.That meant she had to try to find a way home.She said: ldquoI have very mixed emotions about being home.ldquoAlthough I am very thankful and glad to be safe and well, I am heartbroken that my trip was cut short.ldquoIt still feels strange waking up in Dunbar knowing I should be halfway across the world!ldquoIrsquove now completed my  days of self-isolation.ldquoDuring that time my mum and sister were kind enough to bring me little care packages and my favourite snacks to keep me going, so I got to see them through the window and over the garden fence, which was lovely.Lucy, of Dunbarrsquos East Links Road, had spent a year saving up to travel to Australia, with a view to volunteering at an animal welfare charity and taking part in charity events and environmental gatherings.However, the coronavirus meant she lost her job working as a bar restaurant manager and with no way to earn money she had to look at coming home.She told the Courier: ldquoI wouldnrsquot in any way say it was a waste.ldquoI got to spend some quality time with my Aunty and Uncle and explore Melbourne.I met some lovely people along the way and had a great time so Irsquom happy to have gone.ldquoI donrsquot have any plan going forward at the moment. Right now Irsquom just focussing on caring for my Gran and keeping us safe and well.ldquoAs the lockdown eases, Irsquoll be looking to get straight back into full-time work to save up for a new adventure in the future!ldquoIdeally, I would love to go back and start my plans over again once this is all over and Irsquove saved up.ldquoBut for now, itrsquos just a waiting game for everyone to see where le will take us next!

title: leuchie-house-need-emergency-funding
story: The charity provides respite for those with long-term neurological conditions and their families but this stopped in March due to the Covid- crisis it has since been assisting the NHS by taking patients from hospitals who longer need medical care but are not well enough to go back home or into community care.Mark Bevan, Leuchie Housersquos chief executive, said that its future was at risk and emergency funding was needed to survive.He said: ldquoWe had to close our doors to guests and that meant we had no guest income and meant we had to stop our usual fundraising events.ldquoWe think we will lose about pound, over the whole period. Wersquore really worried that we will not be able to start the service off again when lockdown eases sufficiently for guests to come back.ldquoThese people will be really desperate for the sort of service that Leuchie provides and we need to keep hold of our staff and keep the building going.

title: residents-bit-back-online-christian-aid-week
story: Christian Aid Week would usually see door-to-door collections throughout the town, with members of the townrsquos churches coming together.However, the coronavirus lockdown meant there had to be a change in the way the money was collected during the annual fundraiser, which took place from May -.An online appeal was launched with residents donating pound, to the charity, which works to support sustainable development, eradicate poverty, support civil society and provide disaster relief throughout much of the world.

title: connections-made-north-berwick-street-singalong-revelation
story: And the tuneful neighbours say the connections they have made during lockdown have been ldquoa revelation.Residents on Balfour Street and neighbouring Quadrant Lane were joining the nationwide Clap for Carers each Thursday evening and decided to take things up a notch.Carol Stobie, a Balfour Street resident of  years, suggested the singalong via a WhatsApp online group set up to connect residents during lockdown. Fellow resident Bill Nisbet, who currently pastors the North Berwick Christian Fellowship, brings his guitar to the street, where Carol joins him playing ukulele.She said the links forged during lockdown have been ldquoa revelation.ldquoThis area has a lot of holiday flats but there are also quite a few permanent residents, said Carol.ldquoSince Natalie Pereira, our street link volunteer for the North Berwick Resilience Group, set up the Whats-App group, wersquove seen so many new connections forming between people who didnrsquot know each otherrsquos names.ldquoNow therersquos always someone offering to drop things off for those shielding, popping to the supermarket, High Street or Post Office.ldquoI hope we can build on these connections after lockdown.Carol is the project officer with Community Connections, which tackles social isolation in the North Berwick area.She said: ldquoOur members are among the most vulnerable folk, many of them shielding. They still show resilience, patience and great kindness to one another.ldquoThis singalong is a symbol of community connection ndash itrsquos just one of many things going on across an amazing community, and I think it reveals what le needs to be like for us all in the future.

title: behind-closed-doors-racing-planned-musselburgh-racecourse
story: The East Lothian course has not held a racing fixture since February due to the coronavirus.Now, action could , after five provisional fixtures, from the end of next month until the end of August, were allocated by racingrsquos governing body, the British Horseracing Authority .The other Musselburgh fixtures are on July , July and August .Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: ldquoWe are planning to resume racing again at Musselburgh on Tuesday June  and Wednesday July  by staging controlled racedays, which will be without spectators.ldquoWe have adapted our operational procedures to ensure these behind-closed-doors meetings meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards.A total of  meetings in June, July and August will be staged at Scottish racecourses, subject to a range of factors, particularly public health and the approval of the Scottish Government.The BHA has released protocols for racing behind closed doors, which includes specic guidance for the racing industry to help safeguard the health of employees and participants in a controlled and managedto racing.The protocols include detailed information for the safe movement of horses, jockeys, racing staff and their equipment.Musselburgh previously confirmed its Stobo Castle Ladies Day fixture in June and its six scheduled flat fixtures in July and August had been cancelled and full refunds will be issued to customers who have purchased tickets.Delly Innes, of Scottish Racing, which represents Scotlandrsquos five racecourses, said: ldquoThe public can have confidence in our ability to race behind closed doors as safely as possible when the government allows more industries back to work.ldquoAs a highly regulated industry we have considerable experience of keeping any potential health and safety risks to an absolute minimum.ldquoWe are fully prepared to stage race meetings in a strictly controlled environment which fully comply with all the requirements of governmental and racing industry bodies, once they decide the time is right to resume racing.Racegoers who have purchased tickets for Musselburghrsquos July and August meetings will be contacted shortly to arrange refunds while customers who purchased tickets in person or by telephone are asked to email musselburghracecourse@eastlothian.gov.uk to arrange a refund.

title: residents-asked-mark-wallyford-childrens-gala-home
story: The annual event, which was due to be held next Saturday , has been cancelled due to the pandemic.But the gala team is urging people to put up bunting outside their houses next week and is hoping the children will make pictures of crowns for their windows.Jacqueline Stewart, secretary of the gala group, said the idea came from Pastor Andrew Agnew of Wallyford Livingroom Church.She added: ldquoWe thought it would maybe lt the childrenrsquos spirits. We donrsquot want our gala court to feel like gala day is forgotten about. It usually attracts a huge crowd.She explained that it was hoped to hold the gala in  which would feature this yearrsquos gala court.Alister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, said: ldquoWallyford Gala has been running as a yearly event on the first Saturday in June for many decades and it regrettable, as with many other events, that it had to cancelled this year due to the present circumstances.ldquoIt would be lovely to still see it given recognition in some way, such as what is being proposed by the gala team, so that it does not slip past without us still having the feeling of the gala taking place.Looking forward to their big day in  are: gala queen, Grace Harnanan gala king, Jamie Lawson chief lady, Tayla Patton ladies-in-waiting, Kiera Harnanan, Sophie Glen and Isla Stewart herald, Freddy Markham train bearers, Nathan McGhie and Mia Halliday crown bearers, Alex Hill and Corynn Laidlaw wreath bearer, Lacy Doman flower girls, Demi Smith, Reagan Cochrane, Lily-May Clark, Olivia Boyne, Hannah McDonald, Ronnie McGhie, Lily Gibson, Olivia Fleming Lea Anderson and Lilly Harnanan page boys, Darren Crawford, Murray Fisher, Joshua Garrity, Rudi Stewart, Travis Rogan, Matthew Brown, Ayden Anderson, Jack Young, Kayden Clelland and Jacob Wilkie.

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: community-resilience-communities-aberlady-gifford-haddington-athelstaneford-longniddry-macmerry-gladsmuir-ormiston
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Aberlady. Picture: Google MapsAberladyABOUT  volunteers are offering support to elderly and vulnerable members of the community in Aberlady and surrounding areas.Since March , nearly  requests for help during the coronavirus lockdown have been fulfilled.Assistance has included shopping for food and other essentials, collection of medical prescriptions and dog walking.A spokesman for Aberlady Resilience told the Courier: ldquoWe are confident that our volunteers will continue to provide help for as long as the current crisis continues."Contact detailsAnyone needing help should contact either Ian Malcolm on   or Sam Robertson on  .Further information and advice is available online at: www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-Gford. Picture: Google MapsGfordVOLUNTEERS in the Gford community resilience team have benefited from a donation of  bottles of hand sanitiser from Glenkinchie Distillery.It joins face coverings, volunteer ID cards and hi-vis vests which have all been offered to the team by the community council, along with support from local residents and businesses.The community councilsaid: ldquoThis is all part of our commitment to supporting our volunteers as much as we can in the vital work that they are carrying out.ldquoWe also gave a bottle of hand sanitiser to each of our nearly  lsquoSoup and a Smilersquo households, along with a copy of the East Lothian Courier for those who do not already buy it.ldquoThis is a great way for us to help residents, who may not be online, keep up to date with essential information about the county.The number of people using the service continues to grow and the community council said they are delighted with the positive response they are getting.They said: ldquoWe now have a dedicated team who safely deliver the food each week and many residents enjoy this socially distanced contact as much as the delicious lunch.ldquoWe are applying for funding to continue and expand this service, as well as looking at other ways we can build on this project.ldquoAs reported last week, we have begun work to understand the impacts that a lt in lockdown and ato some form of normality in terms of work or education might mean to our network.ldquoWe have been delighted with the response from volunteers, who have committed to continuing to help in some form. This community spirit and dedication to supporting others is very much appreciated by all of us.Contact detailsAnyone who needs support or wants to help can contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or The Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonE-MAILS are being sent out to ensure there are enough volunteers in Haddington to cover those going back to work.Lockdown restrictions will be eased at the end of this week, with a number of volunteers ing to work.Haddingtonrsquos community council has been at the centre of voluntary efforts to ensure vulnerable people are getting the assistance they need during the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, the grouprsquos vice-chairman, was confident, even with volunteers stepping back, there would be enough people to continue offering the same level of help.
